attributes.alt: Book cover for Ofrenda, written by Maricruz Hernández Álvarez and illustrated by Carolina Farias. The cover art shows a grandmother holding a child who has flowers in her hand.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters
, engage children with a song, and introduce a new vocabulary word
What do you see in Ceci’s neighborhood?
Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and lowercase letters in isolation.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
What is it like where we live?
Look at the pictures. What is one place that you see?
Pretend there is a pizza shop in your neighborhood. You can be a customer or a pizza maker.
What shapes can you use to make a building?
I’m going to write the name of our neighborhood on the board. Can you trace the letters?
Draw a picture of something in your neighborhood that makes you happy.
The playground in Ceci’s town looks like a lot of fun. Use the blocks to build a really cool playground.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
, and introduce two related vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and notice when Ceci and her grandma are persisting in their tasks.
Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Guide children to use persistence when trying to throw beanbags into a hoop or bucket.
Invite children to share their experiences with persistence.
What’s it like to live where we live?
What does the town in that book look like?
Who is your favorite town helper? Dress up like that person!
Make buildings. Use scissors and papers to cut shapes.
Draw your favorite place to play in town.
Make a collage to show things in our neighborhood. You can draw, use cut-out pictures, and even use leaves and other objects.
. Make your own letter with your finger in shaving cream.
Do you live in a house? Apartment? Use blocks to build it.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, review letters of the alphabet, and introduce a new vocabulary word
What do you see that lets you know this is a city?
Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.
Invite children to illustrate a three-word book.
Allow time for children to share their books.
What is it like where we live?
How is the community in the book like yours?
Why is pretending with friends so much fun?
Count the buildings on each page of
. Show with blocks how many you counted.
Do you live in a city or small town? Draw a picture of it.
Dip the foam letters on a stamp pad. Make an alphabet letter sign.
Use blocks to build a community of houses and buildings. Which blocks will you need?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the neighborhood  and introduce vocabulary words
Start Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question,
What is it like where we live?
Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Our Neighborhood. The chart shows houses, a school, stores, and a park.

elements.text: Have children take turns choosing a place in the community to draw.
What is it like where we live?
Compare where we live to where Ceci lives. How are they alike? How are they different?
Pretend you are at a park. What do you see? Act out what you do.
Let’s count all the streets on the Big Chart.
Which building on the Big Chart is the most important? Tell me why. I will write the words.
Let’s create a neighborhood like the one on the chart. Which materials would work best?
What letters do you see in the word
Can you build a whole town? You can use any materials from the building station. What will you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to sing about a turtle, use their imaginations to create images, and introduce vocabulary
How is your neighborhood like Ceci’s?
Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What do you like about your neighborhood?
Save children’s work to display next week.
What is it like where we live?
Imagine this story was about your neighborhood. How would it be different?
Pretend you are a mail carrier. What do you need to do?
Look at the Big Chart. Let’s count how many shops, houses, and places to gather there are.
Write about your day so far today in your neighborhood. Where did you go? What did you see? Who did you talk to?
Can you make a sculpture of your house? You can use any of the materials here.
Let’s use Magnetic Letters to write the name of our town.
Work as a team to create a city! Make a lot of tall buildings using any materials.
